Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Update schema availability attributes" (#411) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: Some of the availability is incorrect in the repo and the source schemas have it different. This updates the data to be more accurate.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Simplify enum parsing utilities" (#408) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: The current parsing logic has a caching mechanism that duplicates a lot of code and allocates a number of unneeded objects. This cleans up the parsing mechanism to cache at the onset with minimal allocations. By moving to its own type (EnumStringLookup), the EnumValue itself can more easily inherit from OpenXmlValueType and get a lot of the error checking for free.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Update office2016 from master" (#410) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Closed issue "OpenXml Does not fully support .Net 4.5 (TargetFramework)" (#407) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
**Description: OpenXml Does not fully support .Net 4.5 (TargetFramework)**

I will have to inform you that the version of DocumentFormat.OpenXml 2.8.1 does not fully support .Net 4.5.2

VisualStudio:
- .NET Target: 4.5
- DocumentFormat.OpenXml Version: 2.8.1

**Repro**
1. Create a .Net 4.5 Target Console Project. 
2. Test the following code: 
_using (SpreadsheetDocument spreadSheetDocument = SpreadsheetDocument.Open(excelStream, false)_

3. Error: Method not found: 'System.String System.String.Format(System.IFormatProvider, System.String, System.Object, System.Object, System.Object)'.

**My conclusion:**
The Method only exists in mscorlib that comes with .Net 4.6..
Please test, and note me if my assumptions are correct. As pr. now i do not have a workaround for this error since i am not allowed to upgrade the .Net version on the environment...
Please send me a mail if you have fixed this and/or if you know of any workaround.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Open xml does not open the Excel file" (#409) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
I have open excel file in OpenXml Productivity Tool 2.5 and seen that the file has missing Properties child elements (Application, DocumentSecurity, ScaleCrop, HeadingPairs, TitlesOfParts, LinksUpToDate, SharedDocument, HyperlinksChanged, ApplicationVersion).
I have open the file using OpenXml library in C# it throws **FileFormatException**. But, when i open the file manually and save it and then open using OpenXml library in C# it works file.
How i add Properties child element in Excel file without opening in OpenXml library in C#.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Simplify enum parsing utilities" (#408) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: The current parsing logic has a caching mechanism that duplicates a lot of code and allocates a number of unneeded objects. This cleans up the parsing mechanism to cache at the onset with minimal allocations. By moving to its own type (EnumStringLookup), the EnumValue itself can more easily inherit from OpenXmlValueType and get a lot of the error checking for free.

Events.RelatedBody: In a previous commit, xunit was updated. Xunit now comes with a number of analyzers that check for best practices, which left a number of warnings in the project. This fixes that.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Update projects to use NuGet and new csproj format" (#148) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
As part of being able to support .NET Core, this change does the following:

- Update to the latest NuGet of DocumentFormat.OpenXml
- Convert projects to use the new csproj format (will allow .NET Standard targeting at a later point)
- Consolidates solution files into one file that has the tool, tests, and examples
- Removes the cmdlets (as suggested by @EricWhiteDev)

Initial support for #116

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "DocumentBuilder merges numbering definitions referencing the same abstract numbering definition" (#84) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
When building a document, `DocumentBuilder` merges [numbering definition instances](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/documentformat.openxml.wordprocessing.numberinginstance.aspx) referencing the same [abstract numbering definition](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/documentformat.openxml.wordprocessing.abstractnum.aspx). This leads to bugs if the numbering definitions contain [numbering level definition overrides](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/documentformat.openxml.wordprocessing.leveloverride.aspx).

For an example, see the [example document](https://github.com/OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools/files/434902/Example.of.numbering.definitions.with.same.abstract.numering.definition.docx) and the [processed version](https://github.com/OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools/files/434917/Example.of.numbering.definitions.with.same.abstract.numering.definition-processed.docx). When opened in Word, the example document displays three lists, each numbered from 1 to 3. After being included in a document built with `DocumentBuilder`, however, the processed version displays as three lists with a consecutive numbering from 1 to 9.

Technically, this is due to the `CopyNumbering` method in `WordBuilder` only creating a new numbering definition if it can't find one using the same abstract numbering definition. Instead, it should use a map like `CopyComments`.

This issue is the cause of a bug in our system, so I'll will start working on a fix.
